citation.article-title: Mycobacterium lacus sp. nov., a novel slowly growing, non-chromogenic clinical isolate.
citation.source: International Journal of Systematic and Evolutionary Microbiology

p.s: Description of Mycobacterium lacus sp. nov.
Mycobacterium lacus (la'cus. L. gen. n. lacus of the lake, where the organism was acquired)
Microscopy shows large acid-fast bacilli with prominent beading.
Colonies on LJ medium are nonchromogenic and can grow at temperatures between 25 and 42°C, optimally at 37°C.
A slowly growing organism with features similar to M. gastri by HPLC and biochemical tests, with the exception of positive nitrate and pyrazinamidase test results and the ability to grow at 42°C.
Positive test reactions are also observed for urease, β-glucosidase activity and tellurite reduction.
Does not grow on 5% NaCl or MacConkey without crystal violet.
Arylsulfatase, Tween 80 hydrolysis and acid-phosphatase tests are weak.
Negative results for the niacin test, semi-quantitative catalase, heat-stable catalase, iron uptake, acetamidase, nicotinamidase and succinamidase.
Genetic testing confirms the isolate as a unique species, based on a unique PRA pattern and 16S rRNA gene sequence.
The 16S rRNA gene shows signature sequences characteristic of slowly growing mycobacteria and unique sequence characteristics in the hypervariable regions A and B of the gene.
Phylogenetically closest to M. malmoense, M. marinum, Mycobacterium bohemicum, M. ulcerans and M. tuberculosis complex.

Susceptible in vitro to all antimicrobial drugs tested [amikacin (MIC 0.1 μg ml-1), capreomycin (5.0), clarithromycin (≤2.0), ciprofloxacin (2.0), ethambutol (2.0), ethionamide (2.5), isoniazid (0.1), kanamycin (2.5), levofloxacin (≤0.5), o¯oxacin (1.0), rifabutin (≤0.12), rifampin (≤0.5)], except streptomycin, with intermediate susceptibility (4.0 μg ml-1).
The type strain is strain NRCM 00-255T (=ATCC BAA-323T=DSM 44577T).
